citation.article-title: Veillonella montpellierensis sp. nov., a novel, anaerobic, Gram-negative coccus isolated from human clinical samples.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Veillonella montpellierensis sp. nov.

Veillonella montpellierensis (mont.pel.li.er.en′sis. N.L. fem. adj. montpellierensis pertaining to Montpellier in the south of France, where the type strain and two other strains supporting the description of the species were isolated).
Cells are coccoid (0·3–0·5 μm in diameter) and occur singly, in pairs or in short chains.
Gram-negative, non-motile, non-sporulating and with a convoluted surface.
Colonies on Columbia blood agar are 1–3 mm in diameter and appear smooth, opaque and greyish-white.
Major metabolic end products are acetic and propionic acids.
Major cellular fatty acids are 12 : 0, 13 : 0, 14 : 0, 15 : 0, 16 : 1ω9cis, 16 : 0, 18 : 1ω9cis and 18 : 0.
Strains contained an unidentified compound, which eluted between 17 : 0 iso and Δ-cis-9, 10-methylenehexadecanoate (17 : 0 Δ-cyclic 9, 10).
Can be differentiated from other species of the genus Veillonella by 16S rDNA and dnaK sequencing.
The type strain is ADV 281.99T (=CIP 107992T=CCUG 48299T) and reference strains are ADV 2216.03 and ADV 3198.03.
